Reason: Full barrier to fish passage. Culverts in poor shape and in need of replacing.
Notes: Potential to do some habitat rehabilitation work on the stream in conjunction with culvert replacements.

Reason: In-depth habitat investigations revealed WCT presence upstream and downstream of crossing. Cold water = short growing season for fish. Could be important temperature refuge during hot weather.
Notes: Initial discussions with MOTI carried out. MOTI is amenable to replacing crossing but no solid timeline identified.
Currently going through Fisheries Act authorization due to sediment basin component of work

Reason: Full barrier to passage, culverts in poor shape and in need of replacing.
Notes: Potential to rehabilitate stream channel at same time as culverts replaced.

Reason: Industry barrier. Excellent quality habitat supporting all life stages of WCT.
Notes: Pure population of WCT confirmed in Lodgepole Creek. Barrier at low flows. Sedimentation and deflection issues identified due to culvert.
Supporting Links: https://www.newgraphenvironment.com/fish_passage_elk_2021_reporting/appendix---197787-197786---lodgepole-creek.html Also see: VAST. 2023. Elk River Westslope Cutthroat Trout passage and habitat investigations. Prepared for Canadian Wildlife Federation by VAST Resource Solutions Inc., Cranbrook, B.C.

Notes: Preliminary design complete, undergoing options evaluation

Reason: Industry barrier. Good overwintering potential for WCT.
Notes: Bull Trout also present in stream.  Winter investigations revealed strong groundwater influence upstream of crossing and at mouth of creek. 70 m dewatered section between culvert and mouth.
Supporting Links: https://www.newgraphenvironment.com/fish_passage_elk_2021_reporting/appendix---197844---tributary-to-bighorn-creek.html Also see: VAST. 2023. Elk River Westslope Cutthroat Trout passage and habitat investigations. Prepared for Canadian Wildlife Federation by VAST Resource Solutions Inc., Cranbrook, B.C.

Reason: High quality WCT habitat cut off from Lizard Creek. Lizard complex including all tributaries identified as critical habitat by working group.
Industry barrier on busy haul road. High value WCT rearing stream with groundwater refugia.
Notes: Preliminary studies by VAST this winter revealed groundwater- influenced temperature refugia and suitable habitat for WCT. EB dominant in lower reaches.
Scores as potential barrier. Barrier to be rehabilitated as part of Teck's Tributary Management Plan under Environmental Management Act.
Barrier to be rehabilitated as part of Teck's Tributary Management Plan under Environmental Management Act

Reason: Important WCT stream with high-quality habitat upstream
Notes: Barrier owner non-responsive. Currently being proposed as offsetting site for NWP Coal. Awaiting DFO decision.
